text: Patient: Yeah well I had the flu and it was pneumonia the same time about three years ago. Doctor: Umm. I don’t know if that’s what it is, but guess what. I’m gonna send you to this good doctor. Dr. S____. He’s right in this clinic also and he’s gonna check you out. He’s probably gonna um make some recommendations about what to do for us to figure this out. But I think that’s important too. Now the good part is you’re already getting the shots. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: And you know your PSA was coming down just from doing that. That part’s great but I don’t want to miss all the little details. I want to be right on top of this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Any questions? Patient: I feel great. Doctor: I was going to say, you look great. I know this is you know waah why can’t we just get this done. But I don’t want to miss anything for you. Patient: Ahhh no I feel great. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I have no problems… Doctor: That’s awesome.

text: Healthcare Professional: Yeah. We can get you started. Family Member: What are the pills? Doctor: Uh, the pills are bicalutamide. So, basically, they, uh, block, uh, your cancer cell from using testosterone that’s in your body. So, right away, they start treating your cancer. Uh. But, when I give you your shot, uh, the testosterone shoots up. It could make your cancer worse in that few days. And, so, I wanna protect that surge of testosterone that occurs when we give you the first shot. Patient: Hmmm. Family Member: The first shot of the hormone? Doctor: The first shot of the hormones. Patient: The body reacts- Family Member: Why would it do that? Doctor: Uh, because basically the medicine is, uh, a protein your body makes and just fools the brain into thinking that there’s too much testosterone, uh, and sort of tells the testicles, “Stop making testosterone.” But that which is there gets released. Family Member: Ahhh. Doctor: And so you just get a surge. And so, Family Member: Ahh.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
